title: Tornado Safety: Your Quick-Action Guide
description: Learn how to stay safe before, during, and after a tornado strikes.

sections.title: Before a Tornado
sections.content:
## Know the Signs

- Dark, often greenish sky
- Large hail
- A large, dark, low-lying cloud (particularly if rotating)
- A loud roar, similar to a freight train

## Prepare Your Home

- Identify the safest room in your home (typically a basement, storm cellar, or interior room on the lowest floor with no windows)
- Make sure everyone in your household knows where to go during a tornado warning
- Remove dead or rotted trees that could fall on your home
- Secure outdoor objects that could blow away
- Have a NOAA Weather Radio with a warning alarm tone

## Create an Emergency Kit

- Water (one gallon per person per day for at least three days)
- Food (at least a three-day supply of non-perishable food)
- Battery-powered or hand-crank radio and a NOAA Weather Radio with tone alert
- Flashlight and extra batteries
- First aid kit
- Whistle to signal for help
- Dust mask, plastic sheeting, and duct tape
- Moist towelettes, garbage bags, and plastic ties
- Wrench or pliers to turn off utilities
- Manual can opener
- Local maps
- Cell phone with chargers and a backup battery

sections.title: During a Tornado
sections.content:
## If You're Inside

- Go to your pre-designated safe room (basement, storm cellar, or interior room on the lowest floor)
- Stay away from windows, doors, and outside walls
- Get under a sturdy piece of furniture and use your arms to protect your head and neck
- Do not open windows (it doesn't equalize pressure; it just lets in damaging winds)

## If You're in a Mobile Home

- Get out immediately and go to the lowest floor of a nearby building or a storm shelter
- Mobile homes, even if tied down, offer little protection from tornadoes

## If You're Outside

- Seek shelter in a basement, shelter, or sturdy building
- If you can't quickly walk to a shelter, immediately get into a vehicle and try to drive to the closest sturdy shelter
- If flying debris occurs while you are driving, pull over and park
- Stay in the car with the seat belt on, put your head down below the windows, and cover your head with your hands and a blanket if possible
- If you can safely get noticeably lower than the level of the roadway, exit your car and lie in that area, covering your head with your hands

## If You're in a School, Nursing Home, Hospital, Factory, or Shopping Center

- Go to the predetermined shelter area (interior hallway on the lowest floor, away from windows)
- Avoid places with wide-span roofs such as auditoriums, cafeterias, and large hallways

## If You're in a High-Rise Building

- Go to a small interior room or hallway on the lowest floor possible

sections.title: After a Tornado
sections.content:
## Immediate Actions

- Check for injuries and provide first aid if you are trained
- Check on nearby neighbors, especially the elderly, disabled, or those with children
- Look out for broken glass, nails, and other sharp objects
- Stay away from damaged areas unless your assistance has been specifically requested by police, fire, or relief organizations
- Watch out for fallen power lines and report them to the utility company
- Stay out of damaged buildings

## Cleanup Safety

- Wear sturdy boots or shoes, long sleeves, and gloves
- Be aware of hazards from exposed nails and broken glass
- Do not touch electrical equipment if you are wet or standing in water
- Never use a generator indoors, in garages, or near windows and doors
- Use a battery-powered flashlight for inspecting a damaged home
- Clean up spilled medicines, bleaches, gasoline, and other flammable liquids immediately

## Communication

- Use your phone only for emergency calls
- Monitor weather reports for updated information
- Listen to emergency officials for information and instructions
